title: NDP 2026: T-Minus 3 Weeks
description: The NDP committee just approved a brand new parade segment and they want a companion app feature for 40,000 attendees. You have 3 weeks to ship it.
storyContext: Three weeks before NDP and your phone buzzes at 2am. The committee just approved a last-minute parade segment, and they want a companion app feature ready for 40,000 attendees. Your team lead forwards the message with one line: "We ship this or we don't ship at all." The office lights are still on. Nobody's going home tonight.

software-engineer.title: Plan the Parade App Feature
software-engineer.instruction: The NDP app needs a feature where spectators can point their phone at parade floats and see fun facts pop up on screen. Put these steps in the right order so the team can build it without breaking the existing app.
software-engineer.hint: What happens if two teams build the same feature at the same time without talking? When should you test the hardest part?

items.label: Write a shared rulebook so different parts of the team can build at the same time without conflicting with each other
Build a quick test to see if the phone camera can actually recognise the parade floats
Set up the servers that send float information to people's phones
Test the new feature inside the existing NDP app to make sure nothing breaks
Simulate 40,000 people using the app at once to see if the servers can handle it

data-scientist.title: Forecast App Downloads
data-scientist.instruction: Marketing needs to know how many people will download the app in the final week before NDP to book enough server space. The graph shows weekly downloads over the past four weeks. Look at how fast the numbers are climbing and estimate where they land next.
data-scientist.hint: Downloads are climbing as the event gets closer. How fast is that climb accelerating?

cloud-engineer.title: Pick a Hosting Plan
cloud-engineer.instruction: The NDP app needs servers that can handle 40,000 people on the day but won't cost a fortune to run the other 364 days when nobody is using it. Which approach do you go with?
cloud-engineer.hint: Your budget has to cover 364 quiet days and one very loud one. What matters most: how much it costs to run, upfront reliability, or flexibility?

options.label: These servers cost nothing when idle and scale up automatically on NDP day. The catch is the very first users each hour may wait an extra 2 seconds while the system wakes up.
Book a fixed number of servers and add extra capacity just for NDP day. Performance is reliable but you pay for those servers even when nobody is using them.
Spread the app across servers all over Singapore so it loads instantly for everyone. Works well for images and text. The float scanner feature may not update as quickly though.
Partner with a local provider that already hosts government services. Data stays in Singapore and reliability is guaranteed. You have less freedom to customise things though.
